intro: Sideritis hirsuta var. chamaedryfolia, commonly known as the hairy rock sedge, is a perennial herb native to the Mediterranean region. It belongs to the Lamiaceae family and is characterized by its hairy, wiry stems and small, lance-shaped leaves. The plant produces clusters of pale blue to purple flowers, which bloom in late spring to early summer. It thrives in rocky, well-drained soils and is often found in dry, sunny habitats. Due to its ornamental value and medicinal properties, it is sometimes cultivated in gardens and traditional herbal practices.
